statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.description: Jerome Dyson had 19 points and Jeff Adrien added 15 as Connecticut beat St. Mary's 89-73 Sunday to remain unbeaten.
article.headline: UConn's home streak at 28 with easy win over St. Mary's
article.linkText: UConn's home streak at 28 with win over St. Mary's
article.story:
HARTFORD, Conn. (AP) -- UConn coach Jim Calhoun thinks freshman guard Jerome Dyson plays basketball like a running back -- and he likes that. Dyson scored 19 points Sunday, many by driving straight through the St. Mary's defense, and Connecticut (No. 8 ESPN/USA Today; No. 14 AP) beat the Gaels 89-73 to remain unbeaten. "Jerome puts so much pressure on you, because he just comes right at you," Calhoun said. "You kind of don't know what to do, because he's coming at you. You're not going to get a charge because he's just going to slide away."
That usually leaves Dyson with an easy basket or a trip to the foul line. He hit six of 14 shots, and six of his 10 free throws. Dyson, who was a tailback in high school, said he's not afraid of a little contact. "I just like to get to the basket," he said. "If I can get the three-point play, than it's better off for me." Jeff Adrien added 15 points and eight rebounds for the Huskies (9-0), who stretched their home winning streak to 28 games. They are opening the season with 11 consecutive home games before their Big East opener Dec. 30 at West Virginia. Connecticut shot 52 percent from the field and never trailed, using stifling man-to-man defense to hold St. Mary's (6-6) to 37 percent shooting, 27 percent in the first half. The Huskies had an 11-2 run midway through the first half to open a 29-17 lead. They built the margin to 21 points with 1:26 left in the half, when Dyson spun in the lane and used a hesitation move to lay the ball in over 6-foot-11 freshman Omar Samhan. The Huskies took a 47-26 advantage into the locker room at halftime. The lead was 56-31 after A.J Price hit Dyson with an ally-oop pass, and on the next possession found him for a 3-pointer. UConn would stretch that to 29 points before coasting the rest of the way. St. Mary's ended up outscoring UConn 47-42 after intermission, giving Calhoun something to use in practice this week. "It was a good performance by us, tainted by about 12 minutes of not playing defense," he said. "I don't think this team is going to have much garbage time, freedom time, this year. Those days are long gone." Samhan, a freshman, had 13 points and 12 rebounds for St. Mary's, his first double-double. Tron Smith led the Gaels with 15 points. Diamon Simpson had 11 points, but hit just three of his 12 shots. "In the second half, I was really proud of our guys, just competing about every possession and keeping it from being worse than it was," said St. Mary's head coach Randy Bennett. The Huskies had 13 blocked shots in the game, but just three from their 7-foot-3 freshman center Hasheem Thabeet, who played much of the game in foul trouble. Another freshman, 6-11 Jonathan Mandeldove, had four blocks. "I think he can help me," Thabeet said. "It's real good, because everybody can step up and play to back up somebody. I had a bad day today, and Jonathan came up and played great." Thabeet and Price each had nine points for UConn and Price had eight assists. Eleven Huskies played at least 10 minutes. The Huskies, who have no juniors or seniors on scholarship, won their first eight games by an average of 29 points, holding opponents to 32.8 percent shooting -- second lowest in the nation. St. Mary's is 0-5 on the road this season. The Gaels have beaten only two Top 25 teams in the last 30 years, Nevada a year ago and Gonzaga the previous season. UConn coach Jim Calhoun needs eight more wins to reach 750 for his career, and just six more to earn his 500th win at Connecticut.
